evidence_span: The insertion energy of oxygen is strongly negative, which means that it is energetically favorable for oxygen to move from the gas phase to interstitial sites in zirconium and the hydrides.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: For oxygen, insertion in octahedral sites becomes successively harder when the hydrogen content increases.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: Insertion of oxygen in tetrahedral sites is less dependent on the hydrogen content.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: It is known that Fe is released very early from the secondary phase particles (SPPs) by irradiation.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: Ni and $\mathrm { C r }$ are not strongly released until high fluence is reached.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: At high fluence, Ni is dispersed in the matrix, whereas $\mathrm { C r }$ remains in clusters [47].

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: The volume change caused by alloying elements in the preferred $\alpha { - } Z \mathbf { r }$ phase is approximately linear with alloying element concentration.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6

evidence_span: Values of $K _ { \mathrm { M e , \alpha - Z r } }$ are given in Table 2. Nickel, chromium, and iron cause a contraction whereas oxygen causes an expansion of the lattice.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: Nb and Sn have a less pronounced effect and these elements are not expected to increase the hydrogen solubility because of local stress.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Calculations of formation energies of point defects show that it becomes increasingly harder to form Zr interstitials when the hydrogen content increases.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Interstitials in hydrides typically prefer tetrahedral sites rather than octahedral sites.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The interstitial formation energy in ε-hydride is very high (621 kJ/mol) where only octahedral sites are available.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: That is a factor of 2 higher than in defect-free α-Zr (315 kJ/mol).

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: For γ-hydride, the formation energy is between 280 kJ/mol and 470 kJ/mol depending on the hydrogen content.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The formation energy is 193 kJ/mol in α-Zr and somewhat higher in most hydrides (248 kJ/mol to 258 kJ/mol for γ-hydride and 248 kJ/mol for ε-hydride).

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The formation energy is 193 kJ/mol in α-Zr and somewhat higher in most hydrides (248 kJ/mol to 258 kJ/mol for γ-hydride and 248 kJ/mol for ε-hydride).

evidence_span: The formation energy is 193 kJ/mol in α-Zr and somewhat higher in most hydrides (248 kJ/mol to 258 kJ/mol for γ-hydride and 248 kJ/mol for ε-hydride).

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: A Zr vacancy concentration of 1 at.% causes a lattice contraction with a volume change of between -0.1 and -0.5 %,depending on the hydride.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: For pure α-Zr, the volume change is -0.44 %.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: 1 at.% Zr interstitials in octahedral sites give a lattice expansion with a volume change of between +1.0 % and +1.1 %

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: For tetrahedral sites, the corresponding volume expansion is between +0.6 % and +1.0 %.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The volume change in pure α-Zr is +1.2 %.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Computed interaction energies between point defects and alloying elements (see Table 2) show that all elements except O attract defects.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: For Ni, Nb, Sn, and O, the interaction energy is small.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk8
evidence_span: SIAs in tetrahedral sites bind hydrogen by an energy between 13 and $1 8 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk8
evidence_span: A hydrogen atom near an octahedral $\mathrm { Z r }$ interstitial is repelled by $1 4 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk8
evidence_span: the growth of the dislocation loop causes a monotonous increase of the volume with a volume change roughly independent of loop size, about 22 $\mathring { \mathrm { A } } ^ { 3 } ,$ interstitial

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk8
evidence_span: The simulations show that for loops with the critical radius, less than 1 at. $\%$ of hydrogen is needed to prevent the collapse

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: hydrogen is more stable inside the (0001) vacancy loop than in random interstitial sites by approximately $4 0 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$ per hydrogen atom (for 10 hydrogen atoms inside the loop)

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: Hydrogen is more stable at the rim of an interstitial dislocation loop than in random interstitial sites by approximately $3 0 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: $\mathrm { C r }$ for which the trapping energy is similar to that of isolated vacancies, $- 2 5 \mathrm { k J } / \mathrm { m o l }$ is computed by first-principles calculations

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: At around $5 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ $( 2 2 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ , the configurational entropy of H dissolved in the zirconium matrix can reach the same magnitude as the enthalpic preference for H to be trapped in vacancies and vacancy dislocations
property_name: temperature where configurational entropy equals trapping enthalpy

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: The lowest energy barrier $\left( 1 2 . 4 \mathrm { k J } / \mathrm { m o l } \right)$ is found between the tetrahedral sites, i.e., the basal tetrahedral site $B _ { \mathrm { T } }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: The transition state for migration of $_ \mathrm { H }$ from the tetrahedral to the octahedral site, $B _ { \mathrm { T O } } ,$ is much higher in energy, i.e., $3 9 . 8 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$ above the energy of the tetrahedral site and $3 4 . 7 \mathrm { k J / m o l }$ above the octahedral site

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9
evidence_span: The direct transfer of H atoms from one octahedral site to the adjacent one exhibits a transition state only slightly higher in energy, $4 1 . 2 \mathrm { k J / m o l } .$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk9

evidence_span: It is found that the alloying elements reduce the diffusion barriers and lead to faster vacancy diffusion. The effect is largest for $\mathrm { C r } _ { \mathrm { \Omega } }$ followed by $\mathrm { N i }$ and Nb.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: Sn introduces anisotropy in the vacancy diffusion. The diffusion is substantially increased within the basal plane close to $\mathrm { S n } .$ , but not axial diffusion.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: Oxygen slows down vacancy diffusion.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: From molecular dynamics simulations, an average diffusion coefficient is obtained with the values $D _ { \mathrm { i n t } } = 5 . 5 \times 1 0 ^ { - 8 } e ^ { - 9 . 4 / ( \mathrm { R T } ) } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: The diffusivity in the basal plane is approximately twice as high as in a direction parallel to the $c$ axis.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: At typical reactor temperatures, H diffuses about twice as fast as vacancies and interstitials move 510 times faster than vacancies.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: At typical reactor temperatures, H diffuses about twice as fast as vacancies and interstitials move 510 times faster than vacancies.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: The present results indicate that the presence of substitution Nb attracts and pins $Z \mathrm { r }$ interstitials and thereby slows down interstitial diffusion in $Z \mathrm { r }$ both basal and axial diffusion.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: Substitutional Sn seems to have a very small effect on the diffusion of interstitial $\mathrm { Z r }$ at high temperatures, but a retarding effect at low temperatures by repelling $\mathrm { Z r }$ interstitials.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk11
evidence_span: Substitutional Sn seems to have a very small effect on the diffusion of interstitial $\mathrm { Z r }$ at high temperatures, but a retarding effect at low temperatures by repelling $\mathrm { Z r }$ interstitials.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: For the relatively small Cr, Fe, and Ni atoms, this effect is most pronounced.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Interestingly, also Nb and Sn have a small tendency to contract the lattice.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: In contrast, interstitial oxygen exerts a positive stress, i.e., it tends to expand the lattice.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Except $\mathrm { N b }$ , all elements shown in Table 2 tend to segregate from the bulk to surfaces.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Most notably this is the case for Sn and Ni.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Cr, Fe, and Ni attract H atoms, whereas the other elements are indifferent.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Cr, Fe, and Ni attract H atoms, whereas the other elements are indifferent.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Ni, Sn, Nb, and O atoms do not show pronounced interactions with vacancies.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: If an interstitial $\mathrm { Z r }$ atom gets close to a substitutional Fe, Cr, or Ni atom, then the alloying elements swap their positions with the $\mathrm { Z r }$ self-interstitial.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: In contrast, Nb binds $\mathrm { Z r }$ self-interstitials quite strongly

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: whereas Sn somewhat repels $\mathrm { Z r }$ self-interstitials.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk12
evidence_span: Most notably, Nb retards the diffusion of $Z \mathrm { r }$ self-interstitials.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_008_chunk13
